page_content='‘Aaron, Brian D (MR # 00360913) Encounter Date: 12/27/2013,

We discussed with Mr.Brian D Aaron extensively the pathophysiology of obstructive sleep
apnea.

We also talked in length about the long term sequelae of untreated obstructive sleep
apnea, such as a higher risk of hypertension, metabolic syndrome, diabetes,
cardiovascular disease( MU/cardiac arrythmias) and stroke.

We also educated him about the short term effects of obstructive sleep apnea, specifically
difficulty in concentration, memory issues, irritability, mood changes, excessive daytime
sleepiness and increased risk for the occurrence of motor vehicle accidents.

He was counseled to not drive if sleepy and to pull over to the side of the road to take a nap
if sleepy while driving,

Explained to him that polysomnogram (PSG) is the only standard and the best way to
diagnose Obstructive Sleep Apnea. All the procedural details were also conveyed.

We discussed different treatment options available for Obstructive Sleep Apnea, including
the gold standard positive airway pressure (CPAP) along with other alternatives ike
mandibular advancing oral appliances and surgical options

(uvulopalatopharyngoplasty and maxillomandibular advancement procedures).

We also explained to him the importance of maintaining ideal body weight and following a
‘900d sleep hygiene in the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea.

We also provided educational material explaining about Obstructive Sleep Apnea.

‘Addressed Mr.. Brian D Aaron's all questions and concems. He voices understanding and
acceptance of this advice.

Mr.Brian D Aaron will be followed up in the pulmonary/ sleep clinic in 2 months. The patient
was encouraged to call with questions or concems in the interim,

‘Again, thank you for allowing me to provide consultative services and to participate
in the care of Mr. Brian D Aaron.

Sincerely,

Dr. Venkata Dodda, MD
DATE: 12/27/2013, TIME: 11.21 am

Pulmonary and Critical Care and Sleep Medicine
OSF St. Joseph Medical Center EMP 1
1805 Eastland Drive, Bloomington, Illinoi

page_content='Pt here for f/u on recent hospitalization for metastatic esophageal cancer, failure to thrive, 
malnutrition, dysphagia. 
Wife reports increasing weakness, inability to get any nutrition in at all. Went to ER 3 weeks 
ago.
Patient and wife wanting PEG tube, but surgery determined he wasn't a candidate. 
Oncology determined there was no other treatment options to offer. 
Wife and patient agree that his goals are comfort focused care and they do not want to return to 
the hospital. 
They elected for TPN through his port to help with energy and hunger.  Pt reports he does feel a 
little more energy. Is unsure if it has helped hunger. They wanted hospice but are not candidate 
with the TPN. Requesting palliative care. 
Pt is unable to swallow anything, including liquids. Is dealing with increased oral secretions. 
Scopolamine patch was ineffective, so going to try sublingual atropine. 
Was unable to take liquid Augmentin, has received one dose of IV Rocephin 2g x5 days for 
potential Pneumonia. 
Reports significant amount of pain in his throat. Was receiving IV pain meds at the hospital 
which helped. Requesting medication for pain. 
Has not had a bowel movement for two weeks. Isn't having abdominal pain, cramping, or 
feeling bloated. 
Pertinent post-discharge needs reviewed and/or addressed: Palliative/Hospice referral 
recommended or placed. 
Review of Systems 
Constitutional: Positive for malaise/fatigue. Negative for chills and fever. 
HENT: Positive for sore throat.  
Respiratory: Positive for sputum production. Negative for shortness of breath.  
Cardiovascular: Negative for chest pain. 
Gastrointestinal: Negative for abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting. 
Genitourinary: Negative for dysuria, frequency and urgency. 
Neurological: Positive for weakness. 
BP 118/82  | Pulse 72  | Temp 97.6 °F (36.4 °C) (Temporal)  | Resp 20  | Ht 5' 6" (1.676 m)  | Wt 
108 lb 2 oz (49 kg)  | SpO2 100%  | BMI 17.45 kg/m²  
Physical Exam
General: frail, chronically ill, in wheelchair, in no acute distress
HEENT: pupils equally round reactive to light, mucous membranes moist, frequently spitting 
CV: regular rate & rhythm, no murmurs
Resp: clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes/rales/rhonchi 
GI: BS present, soft, nontender, no masses
Ext: no pedal edema bilaterally 
Skin: port in right chest without surrounding erythema or drainage
